column1: Underneath the swift-flowing water of a deep river
column2: the nymph who was the mother of Aristæus sat on her throne. Fishes darted round her white feet
column3: and beside her sat her attendants
column4: spinning the fine strong green cords that twine themselves round the throats of those who perish when their arms can no longer fight against the force of the rushing current. A nymph sang as she worked
column7: that told one of the old
column8: old tales of man's weakness and the power of the creatures of water
column9: but above her song those who listened heard a man's voice
column10: calling loudly and pitifully.The voice was that of Aristæus
column11: calling aloud for his mother. Then his mother gave command
column12: and the waters of the river rolled asunder and let Aristæus pass down far below to where the fountains of the great rivers lie. A mighty roar of many waters dinned in his ears as the rivers started on the race that was to bring them all at last to their restless haven
